subject: docs: dynamic mux support
commitMessage:
docs: dynamic mux support

Added a high level document to support dynamic mux detection and
configuration via EM. It supports both i2c mux as well as gpio
based switch

Signed-off-by: Vijay Khemka <vijaykhemkalinux@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I5ed6a35c4fef194d871732d2c3207c6a9ff82df3

This is just a high level draft and will add more updates. Just wanted to everyone's feedback if I am going  in the right direction.

(3 comments)

Mostly a few phrasing cleanups, and one requested move.

However, I still don't understand why you say this is for GPIO switches and not GPIO controlled muxes.

The part you site is a mux; the agreement is that you will only configure devices on a single mux leg in this external (to the kernel) gpio controls.

If you agree perhaps the paragraph should also be in the alternatives somehow, eg dynamically describing a gpio mux to the kernel.

PS: please CC me when the code is ready for review.

Patch Set 10:

At this point I'm satisfied that a design that meets limited requirements can be implemented without changes to other components, and am removing my -1.   I'll consider a +1 after seeing others review.

@Andrew Jeffery  I convinced Vijay the devices he was referring to actually was a mux with enables and that, since the selectors were decoded, should be called a mux not a switch.  This may have caused your feedback for switch vs mux to be broken, I'll let you decide.

I'll encourage the other reviewers to read the latest draft and refresh any comments.

Patch Set 10:

> 
> At this point I'm satisfied that a design that meets limited requirements can be implemented without changes to other components, and am removing my -1.   I'll consider a +1 after seeing others review.

> @Andrew Jeffery  I convinced Vijay the devices he was referring to actually was a mux with enables and that, since the selectors were decoded, should be called a mux not a switch.  This may have caused your feedback for switch vs mux to be broken, I'll let you decide.
> 
> I'll encourage the other reviewers to read the latest draft and refresh any comments.

Thanks Milton, really appreciate your time on this.

Thanks Vijay.

Patch Set 12:

ping.... Any more comments, thoughts?
Any particular reason the design doc template wasn't used? (https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/design-template.md)
Sorry, I will use the same.
nit:  Not really true.  It handles nested muxes today, just can't handle muxes within an entity, as that somewhat breaks the model a little.
mux under entity would turn out to be nested one. As currently we only support channels list under single mux but don't go further beyond channel.
Right.... that's different than "no support"
Ok, will change language.
This also means that muxes on add in cards can't be used, as add in cards could be detected dynamically.  That's not going to meet the overall needs.
Ack

This requires all downstream consumers to be "mux aware" as they'll need to look for both their normal config, and within a mux config.

We should be simply passing the calculated mux bus to the daemon, which already has a variable, we just need a new variable for each leg of the mux.

I don't think that downstream consumer should be mux aware as they would get calculated bus number and address. So for those daemon it will be like device on i2c with calculated number and address as if it is on motherboard.

Am I missing anything here.

$index is already used to defined the instance of this device that was found, which doesn't really meet the intent of this.  You want the name to match the mux definition itself.


the "name" of the channel shouldn't include I2C.  That is implied.
Ack
The mux channel itself shouldn't have a "type" of a thermal sensor.  There needs to be another TMP421 exposes node that fills in the $bus parameter.

either we can have under every mux channel, have an array of device nodes and each node can provide device details or we can copy channel number in each device node as many times each channel have only 1 device. That's why I didn't create another array here.
Or.... we can simply enumerate the mux paths naming into the language parser, like we do with other things like bus, and forward the data onto the relevant daemons.

We will be parsing these arrays and create an independent node for each type of sensors or other device required by other daemons. After parsing it will look like a static entry as a json object with all parsed information like bus and address.

How it's being detected which Mux is it? How to differentiate between Mux and Switch? They behaves differently, but have only one control register. How to differentiate between 4 and 8 channels muxes/switches?

BTW, PCA9545 is a 4-channel switch.

> How it's being detected which Mux is it?

See line 109, which determines which mux it is, which is determined by the probe statement, which was omitted from this, because it's already well defined and documented elsewhere.

> How to differentiate between Mux and Switch?

Type would be the cannonical way to differentiate.

> They behaves differently, but have only one control register. How to differentiate between 4 and 8 channels muxes/switches?

Also type, like we already do for other muxes today.

> 
> BTW, PCA9545 is a 4-channel switch.

+1.  Seems like something to fix.

> See line 109, which determines which mux it is

So, the topology (at least, for muxes/switches) configuration is predefined?
Topology for a given board/system is defined in config files.
Yes this is just an example config for user to create board specific topology. And I will fix name as 4 channel mux.

As I alluded to above, this somewhat breaks the exposes model.  an NVMe temp sensor module should not need to be aware of the mux at all, it should just be given a bus number and the mux handled transparently.
We must know what address and what channel number mux has this. Logical bus number would be defined by mux based on channel info.

Another approach is to describe the relationship between a known bus and the desired muxed bus, and then have the code find the parent bus from the parent and child port numbers.

Similar to that how USB sysfs device path is huba-port/hubb-port/device i believe the sysfs for i2c is bus/bus/bus/device with a description linking to the mux control.  So the code would walk sysfs to find the needed bus.

If we have mux driver added in dts then we can describe relations and code can find out. But we want to keep DTS as lean as possible and have multiple configuration for different board for same platform. There are some cards are dynamically detected as a riser card which may or may not available.

But I can add this approach also in the document, Thanks.

I was hoping there was already a method to add a mux device but reading this we may need to propose something maybe configfs driver to create platform data

https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/Documentation/i2c/muxes/i2c-mux-gpio.rst

"We must know what address and what channel number mux has this. Logical bus number would be defined by mux based on channel info."

The NVME device doesn't know the address or channel number today.  It only needs to know the bus number, which we already have a mechanism for passing around in a dynamic way (using $bus)


What Milton suggested is roughly what I would recommend as well.
bus and channel number can be detected vi EEPROM if they have one.

I think the point is we might consider a static setup to get a bus segment, but if you need to change the selectors then it needs to be done by the kernel so the normal drivers work.

It can be a driver for each topology like tv tuners or an new configurable generic one.

Yes that's true and it will be identified by type like we do currently for PCAXXX type. We read this as a type from config file and then bing this kernel driver. We can define multiple different type which has specific kernel driver.

How does this work at the kernel interface level? Are you proposing we use new_device and bind the i2c-mux-gpio driver to it? If so we need a mechanism to describe the GPIOs to the kernel. Or are you proposing handling this in userspace somehow?

I feel this (again) starts us down the route of devicetree overlays or connectors.
Looks like I am missing something here. This is for gpio based mux switch. As we are using one of https://www.diodes.com/assets/Datasheets/PI5C3253.pdf and I am thinking of supporting this.
Right, but *how* are you going to support it?
This one is just a switch and I guess this doesn't need any driver. Only enable/disable GPIO lines and use gpio for selecting slots.

Which would also imply no kernel drivers for devices
under it (seeprom, thermal sense etc)
For devices under it like sensors, we can bind it from entity manager. eeprom, we may not need it as fru-device read it directly via i2c read.
If the mux is just a buffer maybe but if you actually have multiple segments that need to be accessed then a kernel mux driver is required.
Yes I agree and we will bind it same way as i2c mux, the first option.
Right, but how do you describe the required GPIOs to the i2c-mux-gpio driver from userspace?

Currently, I am not covering those with gpio driver. Only mux switch enabled/disabled by gpio is covered here. i2c-mux-gpio can be added through DTS currently. I am open for suggestions.

So current scope will cover PCAxxxx type and gpio based switch. This itself is going to be a big implementation and will add more enhancement slowly.
Ack

I think others have already weighed in here, but I don't understand how GPIO based muxes are going to work.  Can we just remove this section until you have a good understanding?

We need to communicate this MUX_BRIDGE_Qx_EN information to the kernel somehow.  Otherwise, how are we going to deal with cross-process interaction of these GPIO pins and how are we going to enable hwmon-based drivers on devices behind these muxes?
Alright, i will remove this section and create a mux switch section which will be justa gpio based switch.
Can we please use "switch" consistently in this section an drop the use of "mux" to avoid confusion?
Ack
Parsing additional layers of configuration is not minimal.
I have analysed impact yet, i am open for suggestion. I can update this section as per suggestion
can you give an explicit part number example here?   Not all PCA family are muxes.
Sure, we generally have all supported PCA muxes added in device.hpp file.

I went back and read all the comment threads, and I think I understand where the contention is:

This paragraph says that Entity Manager is going to use GPIOs exposed by the platform to add logical busses.   To allow devices under more than one mux channel, the kernel needs to control the mux to allow proper access locking of the i2c bus.

The current kernel mux code has support for gpio control through the device tree, or through a configuration structure passed via platform data.   For a truly dynamic addition someone will need to add a kernel driver.

If the goal of these entity manager patches is just to describe which bus its on then I'm ok with having it follow sysfs though the mux to find the i2c bus number assigned to the segment.  But if there is more than one segement that can have a device at a time, the kernel must be aware and in control.

Entity manager job is just to find logical bus number after mux driver gets initialized and map back to it's device configuration. None of devices are accessed without kernel driver so kernel will be aware of all of those operations.

what do you mean by "after initializing mux driver via entity manager" ?

I thought this was dynamically instantiating a mux driver.   If its just deferring instantiation of devices behind a planar mux I'm ok but would like some wording changed.  (I don't see code upstream to supply a generic mux config via GPIO, but PCA muxes should self configure).

Your text and examples below says you will set some gpios then call a kernel driver.  But you are showing conflicting states of those gpios and have not described any exclusion.

Mux driver would be dynamically instantiated by entity manager only via overlay code which is currently happening in current code. As soon as it gets instantiated logical bus number would be populated for each device behind mux and then those device driver will get instantiated on a logical bus and given address.

I am in the process of having code for finding logical bus number and updating configuration file.

Do we basically put an I²C topology for all the FRUs that has multiple I2C muxes and each of them will have fixed number of connections? Is this only for like sensors?

What if we want to have dynamic connection like a FRU that has multiple slots that connects to more FURs. Will that work?

With that it is not guarantee that all the FRUs are connected. Those FRUs will be a board itself. Do we just want a mapping to the address/bus that we know... and then look at the actual FRU instead?
For the FRUs, does the Entity Manager just have to keep track of this mapping and update the Slot name on the board/FRU if it is suppose to be connected to another board/FRU.

Let me clarify here, FRU is mainly used for detecting and probing to get a bus number. If you have bus number predefined and want to have different probing mechanism, entity manager doesn't care as long as probe returns true it will add the respective config file. And if any $bus or $address is used in that file it will be replaced by actual i2c bus number found by FRU interface.

Each mapping is separate for each found card.
Will this bus number be replaced by the logical bus number? If so, is there a plan how to replace?
Yes, i am working on code for this. I will update design once I have complete working code.

I was wondering how to implement this. In order find the logical bus number, you need to know the $bus, $address and $channel. $bus.Slot_1 is not unique, when you have multiple mux devices on a I2C bus.
you already know $bus, you are getting address and Slot_1 is your channel number.

Jie is right. It is possible to have more than one I2C mux on the same $bus. e.g. one at 0x70 and another at 0x71. I haven't personally run into this situation, but I suppose it could happen.

Slot_1 is specified in the ChannelNames list above. So maybe this is fine as is? The user can select different names for the second mux.

if you you have a nested device with Bus property "$bus.Slot_1_0", you might not find the logical bus number, as "$bus.Slot_1" might bot be unique. You need to know the address of "$bus.Slot_1" that is not shown the device properties.

logical bus number are directly mapped to channel names and are unique. So as soon as we see these channel names we will try to find its logical bus number and create a map. Then while parsing $bus.Slot_1_0 will be replaced accordingly. I am even thinking of keeping these as 2 separate field as I am finding difficult in parsing everything in the same property. I will update this as a next patch after verifying implementation.

That part is definitly a input pin controlled mux, with additional enable controls that is beyond the current mux framework that the i2c gpio mux driver uses, but could easily be extended to suppot.

Are you trying to only use one channel of the above device to implement a switch?

Maybe we need to split the two use cases.
We can certainly add more support of kernel driver. Currently we are going to support pin controlled switch.
I added a statement above at 43 in patch 6.  If its more than an off-off switch and you need devices on more than one channel, the kernel must control the mux.

It is just a on/off switch to enable a particular device. Once device is enabled then its kernel driver will be initialized. For each board there will be one configuration which will expose certain channel. And it is one time, EM is not going to switch back and forth for controlling mux.

The part you showed can only enable one downstream segment, because the selectors are decoded and not one-hot enables.  So is entity manager also going to take care to unbind all switched deivices before allowing any other device to be selected?

Otherwise we are back to needing a kernel driver for this mux application.

Your example shows 2 TMP421 on different channels.

My assumption here is all the devices are one time configuration at a particular running session. But I agree if we change switch selection then it needs to unbind all devices. Currently I will keep it simple with single type configuration and add more complexity later on.

So you are conceeding the limitations but they are not stated.

A significant limitation is only one downstream port without a driver, and some method to enforce that only the first used is selected.

Alternatively an appropriate driver removes the limitations but if you have both now you need to differentiate which applies.  An overlay as described sounds like a good plan (although I have not researched what is upstream vs popular downstream).

If you express the limitations here and how they are enforced I'm ok with a tactical solution.
Sure I will update documents with the one downstream port limitation and overlays.

I think we need a better statement of what benefits we are getting by not describing the mux to the kernel with a proper i2c mux driver.

If the only benefit is describing to entity manager what to probe on a given bus then lets clearly state that.
We are getting a dynamic access to any add on card so we don't need to describe this in kernel earlier. It will eventually get added as soon as card is detected via entity manager configuration.

Where are the gpio and isolator physically?

You said the gpios should be named why not describe the connection to the muxes?

If the gpios are on the support to the plug in card with different muxes on the card then this makes some sense.  However if they are on the same card, especially if you expect to have more than a static configuration once a set of cards are plugged, then it should be kernel controlled.

I don't have a strong sense of how the userspace learns the content of the cards, other than it should be reasonably easy to describe and create by humans as well as machines.

This gpio switch is on main board but it can be anywhere. It is completely dynamic and you define slot number based on gpio line combinations. So EM will set those gpio lines before accessing each slots card. a great example for that is battery sensors.

User space has to dynamically detect which card is connected and what all it has via configuration file. So kernel have no idea what card is connected in expansion slot until it's driver is initialized.
This is in alternatives considered, so we do not need to debate how user space control is a broken model.
This dynamic model is provide a flexibility to configure a board with certain configuration.

If it resolves the bus number then state that.   But I don't understand why entity manager is involved more than a hotplug enable switch.   It can't be in control of the mux if there are sensors below, and any vpd has to be removed before changing the mux from userspace.
EM is not controlling mux, it is detecting devices based on configuration and providing device details to other daemons.

Current -> the initial

will only support
Done

No all devices won't be visible this is my point.

You must put code in entity manager to not consider other legs once one port has been selected with this design.
Done

An advanced design.

Could iterate through the mux selects binding and unbinding all devices.


The preferred design installs and configures an i2c mux driver so the kernel will expose i2c bus segments for each select and control the mux dynamicly.
Done
and needed -> that need
Done
Missing space EM. This
Done

support a single ... in a single configuration
line and other devices won't be
Done

Ok but perhaps binding, reading vpd, then unbinding.
To give a reason to do the extended version.

Also an advanced design
Upon further thought, this "An advanced design" should probably be moved to the alternatives concidered section.
Ack

I don't understand what you are trying to convey with this paragraph.   As noted earlier that is clearly a mux with additional enable signal.   Multiple legs can not be selected because the select inputs are 2:4 decoded.

Unless you want to expand on having an in kernel driver, this might be extraneous.
There was a comment in starting as this is not a gpio mux so I called this as gpio switch. And I have mentioned this type of gpio enabled mux device would be supported currently.

Well, I still say this is a gpio controlled mux, so I don't understand what its trying to convey by claming its not a mux when the linked part clearly is.   Unless you have some other definition of mux; mine is an shortening of multiplexer, a device that selectively selects one of several channels to a common connection (or some refinement of that).
ok, I will update as gpio controlled mux.

Can you point out this loadOverlays API ?   Is it upstream?

I know the syntax and dtc compiler support has been around since 2018 and has been used in the raspberry pi community, but wasn't sure its available in the base kernel yet (the recent discussion on reserved devices seems to agree)


Otherwise, I'd propose:
The initial design will only support a single selection.   Once a port is selected for use other ports will not be selectable and thier devices won't be selectable.

If you are proposing dt overlays be loaded and its not upstream those should be moved to the alternatives considered.

As I've said, describeing a mux that is always presnt is always desirable; it appears this design adds some userspace tooling to entity manager to help describing cards that may be plugged in.
ok, I will update for single device selection.
An advanced design
Ack
this duplicate line 120-125
This is just an example, I will correct it.
Thanks for correcting it. Please see my comments in the newest patch.
Slot_1_1 occur at two places line139, line115. Which one will be used here?
This is just an example, I will correct it.
I understand this is an example. But to wrap my head around the design, I am walking through the config file example below and expect to match the above topology. Please see my question below.
I have tried to follow config as per topology only. Please check once again and I have replied to your other comments as well.
logic bus for this channel is 68
yes this is correct, it is 68
This is at 68-0070 in i2c topology. $slot_1 translates to 68
yes it will be updated by EM to "Bus": 0x68. I don't see anything wrong here
No issue, just confirming
$slot_1_0 is logic bus 70
yes, It will be updated by EM after enumeration.
This should be $Slot_1 according to i2c topology line 59. am I missing anything?
It is correct. Slot1 ends at line 58 and slot_2 starts at line 59 which has 8 channel mux
I may not reading the topology correctly. To me, it show 8 channel mux at bus 68-0072, and bus 68 is Slot_1 showed by line52.Slot 2 would be bus number 91 (line65)

Intuitively, these names would be Slot_1_0 to Slot_1_7. But that would be duplicating line 114-117.
From the code review, I see channel names can not be duplicated. So maybe a different word or pattern can be used?
Sorry to picking on the details, but I think it is important for understanding the design proposal and for the feature to be used correctly by other people.
It is also correct, please see my earlier comment on line 134
I get it now. Let me correct this.
